abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Thermal Power Project
            for Ghana were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory; the risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and the Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: when technologies in the
            energy sector are new to a country, the length of the
            Operations and Maintenance (0&M) contract should extend
            at least up until the first major scheduled overhaul of
            power plant to ensure that the entire project cycle is
            covered. This ensures better and sustained transfer of
            knowledge of power plant management. Furthermore, instead of
            as assigning individual contracts for sub-tasks of
            constructing power plant, a single contract such as an
            Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) contract can
            ensure better performance of overall plant operation. The
            use of the Quality Based Selection (QBS) method could have
            contributed to ensuring a tighter and higher quality
            supervision of the contractors for the power plants, and
            enabled reduction in the significant errors that were made
            during construction, which in turn led to the delays
            in-completing the construction of the power plant optimal performance.
